Glycerol steam reforming on bimetallic NiSn/CeO2–MgO–Al2O3 catalysts: Influence of the support, reaction parameters and deactivation/regeneration processes L.F. Bobadilla ⁎ A. Penkova A. Álvarez M.I. Domínguez F. Romero-Sarria M.A. Centeno J.A. Odriozola Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Sevilla, Centro Mixto Universidad de Sevilla-CSIC, Av. Américo Vespucio 49, 41092 Sevilla, Spain Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Sevilla, Centro Mixto Universidad de Sevilla-CSIC Av. Américo Vespucio 49 Sevilla 41092 Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Present address: Institute of Chemical Research of Catalonia (ICIQ), Av. Països Catalans 16, 43007 Tarragona, Spain. Tel.: +34 977 920 200. Graphical abstract NiSn bimetallic catalysts supported over Al2O3 modified with different promoter (Mg and/or Ce) were prepared and characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 sorptometry, and temperature programmed reduction (TPR). Hydrogen production by glycerol steam reforming over these catalysts was investigated. Among the catalysts, NiSn/AlMgCe catalyst shows the highest hydrogen yield as well as the best stability during the reaction. The effect of reaction temperature, water/glycerol molar ratio and space velocity on the glycerol steam reforming over NiSn/AlMgCe were also investigated. Finally, it was verified that the catalyst can be regenerated by oxidation of carbonaceous deposits. Keywords Glycerol steam reforming Hydrogen production Reaction parameters Deactivation/regeneration 1 Introduction With the depletion of fossil fuels and the environmental problems resulting from their combustion, it is urgent to find new energetic alternatives replacing the fossil fuels [1]. Hydrogen produced from renewable resources such as biomass appear to be one of the most effective solutions for the future due to the carbon neutral emissions and their lesser effects on the environment [2]. Among the products that may be considered as derivative of the biomass, biodiesel takes a special importance. Biodiesel is produced via transesterification of vegetable oil or animal fat reacted with methanol or ethanol generating about 10wt.% of glycerol as by-product. The growing production of biodiesel expected for the next years implies that a high quantity of glycerol will be generated in the future as a waste of biodiesel production and the current market for glycerol will not be able to absorb the expected quantities of this by-product [3–5]. In this respect, the search of alternative uses of glycerol becomes an essential and the hydrogen production from glycerol is among the most attractive. Hydrogen can be produced from glycerol by catalytic steam reforming [6], oxidative steam [7], and autothermal method [8] or by aqueous phase reforming (APR) [9]. Steam reforming is one of the most used reactions since although is highly endothermic the low pressure favors the selectivity to hydrogen. Different catalyst formulations have been proposed for the glycerol steam reforming using metals having the ability to cleavage of CC, OH and CH bonds of the hydrocarbon. In comparison with noble metal-based catalysts, nickel is one of the most promising active phases because of its low cost and wide availability, especially if it was highly dispersed over the support. However, its higher tendency to deactivation by coking and sintering are the main causes of catalyst failure. In previous studies devoted to improve the stability of Ni-based catalysts, Dumesic's group [9] have proposed that addition of Sn results in an increased selectivity to hydrogen production by decreasing the selectivity toward the formation of alkanes (precursors of the coke formation) of these catalysts. The nature of the support strongly influences the catalytic performance of Ni supported catalysts in the steam reforming of alcohols: (i) it activates the dissociation of water into hydroxyl groups and promotes the migration of these species toward the metal particles, where formation of CO x and hydrogen takes place; and (ii) it contributes to the stabilization of the metal particles at high temperature under steam [10–13]. Among the metallic oxides, alumina-based supports are often used in reforming processes because of their mechanical and chemical resistance under reaction conditions. Nevertheless the acidic site of the alumina surface favors the alcohols dehydration generating ethylene and/or other coke precursors. Thus, basic additives or promoters that favor water adsorption and OH surface mobility are typically added to the Al2O3 in order to neutralize its acidity, so lowering the rate of coke deposition on catalyst surfaces [14]. Alternatively, coking may be reduced by gasification of the deposited carbon species [15–17]. The addition of alkaline components such as MgO, K2O [18] or lanthanide oxides [19–21] is usually used to favors the gasification of coke. The combination of adding a basic promoter and an alloying element like Sn must result in active and coke-resistant Ni catalysts, adequate to be used in hydrocarbons reforming reactions. In this work both strategies have been used in order to obtain active and stable catalysts for glycerol steam reforming reaction. A series of catalysts formulations based on NiSn as active phase and γ-Al2O3 modified with MgO and/or CeO2 as support were tested under the most optimal conditions predicted from the thermodynamic analysis to maximize the hydrogen production (650°C, water/glycerol molar ratio=12 and atmospheric pressure). The effect of the operating conditions (temperature, space velocity and molar composition feed) and the catalytic stability were investigated on the most optimal catalyst. Finally, deactivation/regeneration processes were analyzed in successive cycles of reaction with longer time of reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation and characterization Spherical pellets of γ-Al2O3 (Spheralite SCS505) with 2.5mm diameter were milled in a high-energy ball milling with stainless steel ball (22 balls, 15mm diameter). Besides, ethanol was added to avoid the agglomeration of particles. The alumina to ethanol weight ratio was 2.5:1. In a typical experiment, alumina and ethanol were mixed and then milled for 2h at 300rpm. This method permitted to obtain Al2O3 with a particle size of 7–8μm, which was used to prepare all the materials used in this study. A series of catalysts supported on milled γ-Al2O3 having a 26wt.% NiSn loading with a 17:9 Ni:Sn weight ratio and variable loading of MgO and/or CeO2 (Table 1 ) were prepared by the impregnation method. All the precursors were impregnated simultaneously with an aqueous solution of the required concentrations of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Sigma–Aldrich) and SnCl2 anhydrous (Sigma Aldrich) to achieve a Ni/Sn=1.88 weight ratio and the corresponding precursor promoter Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Sigma–Aldrich) and/or Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (Sigma–Aldrich). The concentrations of all the precursors were adjusted to generate the loads indicated in Table 1. The solids were dried at 100°C overnight, and then calcined at 700°C for 12h in flowing 0.1%NO x /He/10%H2O/synthetic air. The calcination process is performed in NO x atmosphere in order to obtain better dispersion of Ni particles [22]. Catalysts were designated as NiSn–Al, NiSn–AlMg, NiSn–AlCe, and NiSn–AlMgCe. In order to compare the supports and catalysts, the solids without nickel and tin were prepared following the same methodology and named in a similar manner but without NiSn. BET specific surface areas, pore sizes and pore volume were measured through nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at liquid nitrogen temperature in a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 apparatus. Before analysis, the samples were outgassed for 2h at 150°C in vacuum. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed in a Siemens D-500 diffractometer. Diffraction patterns were recorded using Cu Kα radiation (40mA, 40kV) and a position-sensitive detector using a step size of 0.05° and a step time of 1s. The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out in a conventional quartz reactor coupled to a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The reactive gas stream (5%, v/v H2/Ar) with a flow rate of 50mLmin−1 was flown through 50mg of sample and the temperature rose at 10°Cmin−1 from room temperature to 900°C. A molecular sieve 13× was used to retain the H2O produced during the reduction. The surface acidity of the catalysts and supports was investigated by means of a Fourier transform infrared spectroscopic (FT-IR) study of pyridine adsorption. Spectra of adsorbed pyridine were recorded on a Nicolet Avatar 380 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector. The samples were pressed into self-supporting disks, placed in a quartz IR cell and treated under vacuum (10–6Torr) at 600°C for 1h. After cooling at room temperature, the samples were exposed to subsequent doses of pyridine until surface saturation and spectra (128 scans, 2cm−1 resolution) were recorded after addition of each one of the doses. The thermal stability of the species formed on the surface was also studied. FT-IR spectra of the fresh and spent catalysts were collected in self-supporting disks of KBr diluted samples using a Thermo Nicolet Nexus infrared spectrometer equipped with KBr optics and a MCT/B detector working at liquid nitrogen temperature. Spectra were recorded at 4cm−1 resolution in the 400–4000cm−1 range accumulating 32 scans. 2.2 Catalyst performance testing The catalytic glycerol steam reforming was carried out in a commercial computerized Microactivity Reference Catalytic Reactor from PiD Eng&Tech, employing a Hastelloy C-276 tubular reactor (Autoclave Engineers) with 9mm internal diameter. Prior to reaction, the catalyst was reduced at 750°C for 1h passing 100mLmin−1 of H2 (50%, v/v in inert). In all the catalytic tests, catalysts were ground and sieved in the size range 100–200μm. Besides, catalysts (100mg) were diluted with quartz (100mg) of the same particle size. Gas products were analyzed on line using a microGC (Varian 4900) equipped with Porapak Q and MS-5A columns and nitrogen as internal standard. Condensable products and glycerol not transformed were analyzed by HPLC (Varian 356-LC) equipped with a Refractive Index Detector and a Hi-Plex H column with deionized water as eluent. In order to evaluate the recovery of catalytic activity were performed three reaction cycles of 18h making intermediates states of regeneration between each one. Reaction conditions were 750°C, water-to-glycerol molar ratio equal to 12 and space velocity 100Lg−1 h−1. The catalyst regeneration was performed at 750°C flowing 100mLmin−1 of nitrogen during 1h to remove the most unstable species and subsequently passing 100mLmin−1 of air during 1h to oxidize the possible coke deposited. After oxidation, the catalyst was activated during 1h flowing 100mLmin−1 of H2 (50%, v/v in inert). The performance of the catalysts was evaluated in terms of glycerol total conversion, X (Eq. (1)), glycerol conversion into gaseous products, X gas phase (Eq. (2)), and glycerol conversion into condensable products, X liquid phase (Eq. (3)). These parameters were calculated based on the following equations: (1) X ( % ) = n glycerol in − n glycerol out n glycerol in × 100 (2) X gas phase ( % ) = n CO + n CO 2 + 2 × n C 2 H 4 + n CH 4 3 × n glycerol in × 100 (3) X liquid phase ( % ) = ∑ i = 1 x i × n i 3 × n glycerol in × 100 where n i corresponding to moles of species i and x i is the number of carbon atoms in the species i. Hydrogen yield (%), Y H , has been calculated from (Eq. (4)): (4) Y H ( % ) = r H 7 × ( − r glycerol ) × 100 where r H and (−r glycerol) stand for the formation rate of hydrogen and the glycerol consumption rate to produce gaseous products, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical and chemical properties of supports and catalysts BET surface areas and textural properties of the supports and catalysts are summarized in Table 1. After adding Ni–Sn phases and CeO2 and/or MgO promoters the surface area and pore volume of alumina decreased considerably, suggesting the incorporation of species that do not form solid solution with the alumina into their pores as early reported [10]. All the unreduced supports and catalysts were characterized by XRD in order to determine the structural modifications provoked by the incorporation of additives. The XRD patterns of all supports and catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . Diffraction peaks associated to Sn and/or NiSn phases were not detected in any case, likely due to the low concentration of tin in the samples and/or to its high dispersion or amorphous character. Al support and NiSn/Al catalyst show all the characteristic diffraction lines corresponding to γ-Al2O3 and nickel aluminate structure (NiAl2O4), respectively. As the amount of Ni added is not enough to transform all the γ-Al2O3 into NiAl2O4, the Ni content of this phase is ca. 33wt.%, it can be assumed that a surface NiAl2O4 spinel coexists with the γ-Al2O3 support. The effect of adding variable amounts of Mg to this γ-Al2O3 support has been discussed in a previous paper [23]. In brief, the incorporation of MgO results in the formation of a MgAl2O4 spinel phase, which inhibits the subsequent incorporation of Ni in the Al2O3 phase (thermodynamically the formation of the MgAl2O4 phase is favored over the NiAl2O4 one thus improving Ni dispersion). If the MgO loading is below 28wt.% both MgAl2O4 and NiAl2O4 spinel phases are present, for higher MgO loadings only the magnesium spinel is formed. The remaining excess of Mg and the added Ni form a MgO–NiO solid solution, due to the high calcination temperature and the complete miscibility of MgO and NiO phases [24–26]. XRD results of NiSn/AlMg catalyst (with 10wt.% MgO) suggested that Mg is incorporated into the alumina support forming the spinel phase MgAl2O4 and coexisting with NiAl2O4 and NiO phases. The XRD patterns of AlCe and AlMgCe supports and NiSn/AlCe and NiSn/AlMgCe catalysts (Fig. 1) show additional diffraction lines at 28.3°, 32.9°, 47.3° and 56.2°, which are assigned, respectively, to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes of the CeO2 phase. At least two phases – the MgAl2O4 spinel structure (JCPDS# 00-021-1152) and the CeO2 fluorite-structure (JCPDS# 34-0394) are present in the XRD of the AlMgCe support and NiSn/AlMgCe catalyst. The crystallite size of CeO2 was estimated using the Scherrer method and the values obtained are represented in Table 1. It should be noted that the size of ceria is smaller for the solids in absence of magnesia which may suggest that the addition of MgO weakens the CeO2–Al2O3 interaction. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) measurements were performed to investigate the reducibility of the catalysts and to analyze the interaction between metal species and the support. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles obtained for catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . The NiSn/Al catalyst shows two reduction peaks at 570 and 798°C. According to literature [27], the first peak is due to the presence of particles of NiO with very small crystallite size. The feature at 798°C is undoubtedly due to the NiAl2O4 spinel reduction [28]. For the catalyst containing 10% of MgO (NiSn/AlMg), the peak at 798°C is partially shifted to 718°C and increases its intensity, suggesting that in this case, the quantity of reducible nickel species is higher than previously and its interaction with the support is weaker although a portion of NiAl2O4 spinel is still existing. This fact reveals that MgAl2O4 is the major component and a part of nickel is presented in the form of NiO strongly interacting with the MgAl2O4 species [23]. The incorporation of Ce in the NiSn/AlCe catalyst provokes a shift of the peak at 798°C to higher temperatures (825°C) and the appearance of a new peak at 450°C. It is well known that the reduction of the CeO2 takes place by withdrawing the oxygen atoms present on the ceria surface at low temperature (450°C) followed by the removal of the oxygen atoms located in bulk CeO2 (900°C) [29]. Therefore, peak at 450°C can be assigned to the easily reducible surface species. A possible explanation of the high temperature shift of the peak at 798°C could be the overlapping of the reduction peak of bulk ceria with the reduction peak of NiAl2O4 species. Similar reduction behavior was obtained for the NiSn/AlMgCe catalyst although in this case the feature attributed to NiO species strongly interacting with the MgAl2O4 additionally appeared [23]. In situ FTIR spectroscopy of small adsorbed base molecules, often NH3, pyridine, CH3CN, NO or CO molecules, has been well established as a powerful surface analytical technique for characterization of nature, strength and concentration of acid sites. Pyridine (Py) has been preferred as an IR probe molecule of finely divided metal oxide surfaces at room temperature and higher temperature regimes, since it is (i) more selective and stable than NH3; (ii) much more strongly adsorbed than CO and CH3CN; and (iii) relatively more sensitive to the strength of Lewis acid sites than NO [30]. In order to investigate the influence of the acidic properties of supports and catalysts in the steam reforming reaction, a FTIR study of pyridine adsorption on the prepared solids has been performed. Fig. 3 shows the FTIR spectra of pyridine adsorption after surface saturation at room temperature on solids without Mg (Fig. 3a) and loaded with Mg (Fig. 3b). All observed bands in all solids are characteristic of pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid centers of the solid; no evidences of Brönsted centers capable of adsorbing pyridine to form PyH+ species (characterized by IR bands at about 1540cm−1) were detected. The adsorption of pyridine on alumina results in appearance of the ν 8a vibrations at three different frequencies, which evidences existence of three kinds of species with participation of isolated Al3+ sites in tetrahedral (1622 and 1611cm−1) and octahedral (1596cm−1) symmetries. The addition of MgO to alumina results in a decrease of its Lewis acidity. Moreover, after pyridine adsorption the band assigned to pyridine coordinated to tetrahedral Al3+ sites located near to cation vacancy (1622cm−1) decreases and the other band associated with pyridine coordinated to tetrahedral Al3+ cations increases and shifts to 1609cm−1. This evidences incorporation of Mg2+ cations in Al2O3 and formation of another phase of MgAl2O4 spinel in good agreement with the results observed by XRD. CeO2 loading on alumina hardly affects the Lewis acidity. Only a slight decrease of the bands due to pyridine coordinated to Al3+ was observed without any changes of their positions. This suggests that Ce n+ cations do not change the structure of the alumina. A band of pyridine coordinated to Ce n+ sites (1599cm−1) was also detected. When both MgO and CeO2 were added to alumina, the Lewis acidity of the sample decreased considerably. A possible explication is the formation of a MgAl2O4 spinel structure that worsens the dispersion of the Ce n+ cations. The absence of the band at 1599cm−1 corroborates this suggestion. The IR bands of adsorbed pyridine on the NiSn catalysts seem to be less intense than those of the corresponding supports. This suggests an additional decrease of the Lewis acidity as a result of the incorporation of Ni2+ cations and the formation of a NiAl2O4 phase. The trends in the acidity modification are very similar but smaller to those observed for the supports. According to Hughes and White [31], the concentration of Lewis acid sites in the supports and catalysts may be estimated from the Lambert-Beer law (Eq. (5)): (5) A = b × C Lewis ∫ e v d v where b is the ratio between mass and surface in the wafer, C Lewis is the concentration of Lewis acid sites, A is the absorbance of the more intense band and the integral corresponding to molar extinction coefficient. The absorbance may be calculated by integration of the band and the molar extinction coefficient is equal to 1.413cmμmol−1. Insets of Fig. 3a and b show the concentration of Lewis acid sites calculated for the supports and catalysts. It can be observed that the addition of MgO and CeO2 decreases the concentration of Lewis acid sites in all solids, and is lower in the catalysts than in the corresponding supports. 3.2 Catalyst performance testing All the catalytic tests were performed using the optimal conditions predicted from the thermodynamic analysis for the glycerol steam reforming reaction to maximize the hydrogen production: 650°C and water-to-glycerol molar ratio equal to 12 [32–35]. A high space velocity (100Lg−1 h−1) was selected to obtain glycerol conversions far away from the thermodynamic equilibrium, which allows observing differences in the catalyst performances, deactivation patterns and intermediates formation at shorter reaction times [21]. Fig. 4a shows the gas phase conversion and moles of hydrogen produced per moles of glycerol introduced vs. time for all the catalysts studied including the results of quartz as blank experiment. It should be noted that the catalytic activity continuously decreases with time up to reach the steady state in all the catalysts and it depends on the support nature although all the materials are performing far from the conditions predicted by the thermodynamic equilibrium. Among the four catalysts, the highest H2 production and gas phase conversion were obtained for the NiSn–AlMg and NiSn–AlMgCe catalysts while the lowest one was observed for the undoped alumina catalyst. Noteworthy that the performance of all catalysts was always superior to the quartz, however one can see that this material was not entirely inert since it presents a significant catalytic activity (glycerol conversion equal to ∼40%). According to Valliyappan et al. [36], the pyrolysis of glycerol to gaseous fuel and other condensable products takes place over a packed bed consisting of quartz or silicon carbide in the temperature range of 650–800°C. Chiodo et al. [37] performed a blank test at 800°C under steam reforming conditions of a reaction stream containing 7% of glycerol and they found that glycerol decomposes in a mixture of gaseous and liquid products resulting in a mixture of CO (50mol%), CO2 (1mol%), olefins (ethylene and propylene ca. 25mol%), CH4 (∼13mol%) and H2 (∼10mol%). Among the liquid products they identified the presence of significant amounts of acetone, acetaldehyde, ethanol, propanol, acetic acid and 2,3-dyhydroxylpropanal. The analysis results of liquids products in the present work indicates that oxygenates compounds such as methanol, acetic acid, ethanol, glyceraldehyde, propanol and acrolein were produced in all catalysts and quartz, although its concentration was remarkably higher in the quartz while in presence of catalysts the liquid to gas conversion was favored. Therefore since glycerol is not a thermally stable molecule the extent of the pyrolysis phenomena plays an important role in the steam reforming conditions and likely the intermediates formed in the glycerol cracking are reformed in the catalysts surface. Table 2 shows the gas phase distribution for all the catalysts and the quartz (blank) after 350min of reaction. The gas phase was essentially composed by H2, CO, CO2, CH4 and C2H4 (ethylene) although the products distribution is a function of the catalyst. The gas product distribution obtained in absence of catalyst was similar to that found for the steam gasification of glycerol by Chiodo et al. [37]. From Fig. 4b it can be observed the effect of introducing Mg and/or Ce in the bimetallic catalysts on the CO/CO2 and CH4/H2 molar ratio. It should be noted that NiSn–Al catalyst presents a CO/CO2 and CH4/H2 molar ratio constant during the reaction time while that the promoted catalysts are increasing or decreasing the ratio during the first 120min. The individual introduction of Mg increases notably the CH4/H2 molar ratio during the first minutes and presents the highest CO/CO2 molar ratio among all catalysts. It shows that the only existence of basic species like MgO inhibits the water–gas shift reaction of CO to CO2 and favors the methanation reaction. The presence only of Ce gives a CH4/H2 molar ratio very similar to that of the undoped alumina catalyst, although with a lower CO/CO2 molar ratio during the first minutes. It indicates that Ce can give rise to CO water–gas shift reaction to CO2 along with a decrease on CO production. The simultaneous introduction of Mg and Ce decreases notably the CH4/H2 molar ratio inhibiting the methanation reaction and diminishes the CO/CO2 molar ratio favoring the water–gas shift reaction. Fig. 5 shows the evolution of ethylene production in all catalysts and quartz. Alcohol dehydration into alkenes would be essentially catalyzed by the support over the acidic sites and therefore the presence of these acidic sites is a key point in glycerol dehydratation to produce ethylene. Results from pyridine adsorption (Fig. 3a and b) showed that the Lewis acid sites concentration in the NiSn/AlMg and NiSn/AlMgCe catalysts were similar and lower than in the NiSn/Al and NiSn/AlCe catalysts. Recently, we have reported a study about the influence of the acid–base properties in the glycerol steam reforming [38] and we have concluded that the presence of acid centers decreases the CC bond breaking capacity favoring the coke deposition and producing ethylene as intermediate. Therefore, the presence of magnesia as basic compound is required to decrease the number of acid centers and avoid the coke formation. Iriondo et al. [39] investigated the effect of ceria promotion over Ni/Al2O3 and showed that the incorporation of low ceria loadings enhanced the catalytic activity but the increase of ceria amounts (20wt.% CeO2) reduced the capacity to convert glycerol into hydrogen. These authors suggested that in presence of high ceria loadings the ceria tendency to interact with alumina instead of nickel avoids the Ni0 stabilization and decreases the Ni dispersion. The performance of the NiSn/AlCe catalyst is in good agreement with these results and the smaller size in Mg absence estimated from XRD confirm the hypothesis suggested by these authors where ceria interact with alumina and decreases the Ni stabilization. Moreover, the catalytic activity is enhanced in presence of Mg and thus a synergetic effect Mg–Ce that improves the Ni dispersion and stabilization could be claimed to occur. We can conclude that the NiSn/AlMgCe catalyst is the most optimal catalyst for the hydrogen production by glycerol steam reforming. Detailed experiments were performed over NiSn/AlMgCe to investigate the effect of process variables such as temperature, space velocity, feed glycerol concentration, and catalytic stability. 3.3 Effect of operating conditions The main objective of this study was to analyze the effect of operating conditions over the NiSn/AlMgCe catalyst. These experiments were carried out by varying the following parameters: temperature, glycerol concentration feed and space velocity. 3.3.1 Effect of temperature The effect of temperature is illustrated in Fig. 6 . Significantly, H2/CO molar ratio increases and CO/CO2 molar ratio decreases with increasing temperature and reaching values close to the thermodynamic equilibrium (Fig. 6a). The hydrogen yield was dependent on the temperature as illustrated in Fig. 6b. Hydrogen yield was increased as a function of reaction temperature up to maximum value at 650°C. The influence of the thermodynamic equilibrium explains the decreasing tendency of hydrogen yield from 650°C. The gas products obtained are mainly H2, CO2 and CO, and the condensable products analysis revealed that different oxygenated hydrocarbons such as acetaldehyde, 1,3-propanodiol, acrolein, acetone, glyceraldehyde, propanal and methanol were presented (Table 3 ). However, the tendency observed in Fig. 6b showed that liquid phase conversion decreases and gas phase conversion increases with increasing temperature. This fact can be explained taking account that glycerol steam reforming is a complex process that includes also dehydration, dehydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions, producing condensable products [40]. The increasing of temperature enhances the conversion to gas products avoiding these secondary reactions that lead to the coke deposition. Valliyappan et al. [41] have proposed a mechanism of metal-catalyzed steam reforming of glycerol similar to that proposed for hydrocarbons [42]. Glycerol molecules are adsorbed dissociatively on nickel crystallites sites, while water molecules are also dissociatively adsorbed on the support sites hydroxylating the surface. Hydrogen is produced via dehydrogenation of adsorbed glycerol molecules and reaction of adsorbed organic fragments with hydroxyl groups, which migrate from the support to the nickel crystallites/alumina interfaces. Activated by the temperature, they eventually form intermediates leading to carbon oxides and hydrogen. At low temperatures, dehydration reactions are promoted, leading to lower hydrogen productions and favoring the routes of formation of condensable products. 3.3.2 Effect of glycerol concentration feed The effect of glycerol concentration feed on the hydrogen yield and glycerol gas phase conversion at 750°C is depicted in Fig. 7 . Notably, hydrogen yield and glycerol gas phase conversion decreased significantly by increasing the concentration of glycerol in the feed. Total conversion was in all cases close to 100% and no condensable products were detected by HPLC. This pointed out that the glycerol not transformed to gas phase products was deposited as coke on the catalyst surface. These results are in accordance with other studies reported in the literature. Adhikari et al. [43] reported similar results using Ni/CeO2 and Ni/MgO catalysts pointing out that the increase in reaction temperature and the water-to-glycerol molar ratio resulted in positive effects both on hydrogen selectivity and glycerol conversion. Gallo et al. [44] studied the influence of reaction parameters on the activity of Ru/Mg(Al)O catalyst for glycerol steam reforming and they observed a decrease of glycerol conversion and hydrogen yield increasing the glycerol concentration in the feed. Therefore, an increase of water-to-glycerol molar ratio improved the hydrogen production and prevented the coke formation. However, the reforming process consumed a considerable amount of energy with the increase in water molar ratio. For example, the total amount of energy required to carry out the experiment at 900°C is about 55% of the heating value of glycerol (1485kJ/mol) with a water-to-glycerol ratio of 9:1, whereas the process requires only 28% of the heating value of glycerol if the reaction is conducted at stoichiometric ratio of glycerol and water (i.e., water-to-glycerol ratio of 3:1) at 900°C [45]. From an economic point of view, it would be necessary to make a balance between the energetic costs and the catalytic deactivation. However, this analysis is far away from the purposes of this study and, for the next discussion, we have selected a glycerol concentration of 30wt.% (i.e., water-to-glycerol molar ratio of 12:1), that is the optimal concentration for the maximum hydrogen production as predicted by the thermodynamic analysis. 3.3.3 Effect of gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) Fig. 8 a and b shows, respectively, the hydrogen yield and the gas products distribution obtained at 750°C and with a space velocity of 50 and 100Lg−1 h−1. It should be noted that the increment in the space velocity resulted in the decrease of both hydrogen yield and catalytic stability. Wang et al. [46] have published the results of thermal decomposition and catalytic steam reforming of acetic acid and hydroxyacetaldehyde concluding that both reactions take place during the steam reforming of oxygenates. The decomposition involves both thermal cracking reactions before entering the catalyst bed and the acid-catalyzed reactions at the acidic sites of the catalyst support [47]. Only very few oxygen-containing compounds are stable enough to reach the catalyst bed without thermal cracking. These competing reactions may form carbonaceous species (coke) significantly lowering the yield of hydrogen and even deactivate the catalyst. The obtained results suggest that, decreasing the space velocity, all compounds are effectively steam reformed, including the secondary cracking products, into H2 and CO2. We believe that the glycerol steam reforming is a catalytic process where glycerol is thermally decomposed to carbonaceous species on the metal particles and subsequently it is gasified by steam into a gas mixture composed mainly by CO, CO2, CH4, C2H4 and H2. Moreover, the presence of ceria in contact with the Ni phase promotes the WGS reaction increasing the hydrogen production and decreasing the amount of CO. When the space velocity is very high, the carbonaceous species are not effectively gasified and the hydrogen yield decreases because of the catalytic deactivation. These agree with our previous results over the hydrogen production from glycerol steam reforming using a monolith catalyst [48]. In such work, and studying the effect of modifying the glycerol residence time in the reactor, we demonstrated the sequential reaction scheme in which glycerol is converted into condensable products and then further reformed to carbon oxides and hydrogen is the residence time increases, condensable products and coke production diminish because they are gasified to gaseous product in the presence of stream. 3.4 Catalyst regeneration Catalyst deactivation during the glycerol steam reforming reaction is mainly due to the sintering of metal particles and coke deposition. In order to investigate the deactivation and regeneration of catalyst during glycerol steam reforming, three reaction cycles of 18h each one were performed. Fig. 9 shows the hydrogen yield evolution in the gas stream during each cycle and it is compared with the blank experiment (quartz). In the first cycle, the hydrogen production decreased with time-on-stream reaching a stable value of ca. 35% after of 9h. At the beginning of second and third reaction cycle, the hydrogen yield was higher than that at the beginning of first cycle, although after 9h the same stable value was reached (≈35%), evidencing that sintering was not the responsible for the activity loss. It should be noted that the steady value of hydrogen yield in the three cycles was always superior to that obtained for the blank experiment. This fact reveals that during the first 9h the coke is blocking some of the active sites but the catalyst was not severely deactivated. The results of cycle 2 and cycle 3 showed that deposited coke on the catalyst is completely removed by the regeneration procedure. To better understand the catalytic behavior during one cycle, we have characterized by FTIR analysis the catalyst surface. Fig. 10 shows the FTIR spectra of the fresh and spent catalyst after 4h and 18h of reaction. Fresh catalyst presents an intense and broad band centered at 3500cm−1 and another one at 1643cm−1 which can be attributed to the stretching vibration of structural hydroxyl and chemisorbed water, respectively [49]. The decrease of intensity of these bands in the used catalyst indicates that, after reaction, the catalyst surface was dehydrated and the new band appearing at 1580cm−1 can be assigned to bidentate carbonate species that are formed over the reduced CeO2 surface [50], although the formation of carbobaceous deposits of aromatic nature cannot be fully discarded. This result indicates that ceria promoter played an important role in the initial catalytic performance. The effect of ceria as support in the water gas shift reaction is well known and although many works have emerged recently, there are a lot of discrepancies about the origin of deactivation of the ceria catalysts in this reaction [51–54]. Among the possible causes, the deactivation of CeO2-based catalysts during the WGS reaction could be due to blockage of the active sites by carbonate and/or formate species. The presence of ceria carbonates in our catalyst after of 4h reaction suggests that ceria promoter was saturated by carbonates species inhibiting the WGS reaction and therefore decreasing the hydrogen production. This is consistent with the work reported by Karpenko et al. [52], which concluded that the deactivation of Au/CeO2 catalyst during the WGS reaction was mainly due to the formation of stable monodentate carbonate species on ceria. The regeneration of the catalysts would be possible removing these carbonates species via calcination in air. Furthermore, Martínez et al. [55] have demonstrated that the activity and stability of catalyst in the glycerol steam reforming are linked to their capability to activate the H2O under reaction conditions and the presence of ceria favors the activation of H2O for a longer period of time allowing the carbon gasification and delaying the deactivation of the catalyst. Sanchez and Comelli [56] studied the deactivation/regeneration process in successive cycles of reaction during the glycerol steam reforming at 700°C on a Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. These authors concluded that the deposition of carbonaceous species on the catalyst surface is the main responsible for deactivation but the catalyst can be regenerated using a He/air stream. However, a small proportion of strongly adsorbed carbonaceous deposits could remain on the catalyst surface. In another study published elsewhere [48], we have observed that during the glycerol steam reforming at 750°C this catalyst was deactivated by carbonaceous deposition into the pores, blocking the interaction of reactive with the active phase. Therefore, during the regeneration step, we can achieve the effective removal of the carbonaceous deposits as well as the transformation of the cerium carbonate again into CeO2, which is a promoter of the WGS reaction. 4 Conclusions The effect of MgO and/or CeO2 promoter on the activity of bimetallic NiSn/Al2O3 catalysts for glycerol steam reforming was analyzed under the optimal conditions for hydrogen production predicted by thermodynamic analysis (650°C, atmospheric pressure and water-to-glycerol molar ratio of 12). The addition of MgO and CeO2 provokes a synergetic effect decreasing the coke formation by suppression of Lewis acids centers and favoring the WGS reaction. The glycerol conversion and hydrogen yield were increased with increasing temperature and decreasing the glycerol feed concentration and space velocity. Increasing the residence time enhances the gasification of carbonaceous deposits and facilitates the reforming process to produce higher hydrogen yield. Finally, we have demonstrated that the catalyst are deactivated by carbonaceous deposits blocking the pores and by carbonation of ceria, but the regeneration of the initial activity is possible by simple treatment with air stream at high temperature. coredata.dc:description: NiSn bimetallic catalysts supported over Al2O3 modified with different promoter (Mg and/or Ce) were prepared and characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 sorptometry, and temperature programmed reduction (TPR). Hydrogen production by glycerol steam reforming over these catalysts was investigated. Among the catalysts, NiSn/AlMgCe catalyst shows the highest hydrogen yield as well as the best stability during the reaction. The effect of reaction temperature, water/glycerol molar ratio and space velocity on the glycerol steam reforming over NiSn/AlMgCe were also investigated. Finally, it was verified that the catalyst can be regenerated by oxidation of carbonaceous deposits.
coredata.dc:title: Glycerol steam reforming on bimetallic NiSn/CeO2–MgO–Al2O3 catalysts: Influence of the support, reaction parameters and deactivation/regeneration processes
